awd_titl_txt: Creating Functional Nanocrystal-Molecule Interfaces for Spin-triplet Energy Transfer
awd_abstract_narration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program in the Chemistry Division supports Professor Sean T. Roberts at the University of Texas at Austin to study light-triggered processes that occur in materials.  Light provides the energy that fuels plant growth via photosynthesis, is used in electronics for wireless communication, and even forms the basis for noninvasive medical treatments, such as photodynamic therapy used to treat cancer. However, light transmits its energy in a peculiar manner, via particles known as photons. Different colors of light contain photons with different amounts of energy, and it is important that photon energies be matched to their intended applications. Photons with too little energy are unable to meet their intended task while photons with too much energy waste energy and can cause damage to components. This research project develops materials that reshape light’s energy content by combining pairs of photons into a single high-energy one or converting individual photons into multiple lower-energy photons. Once formed, these materials can serve as energy transfer agents improving solar energy harvesting and quantum computation. In addition to working with students closely on the research projects, Professor Roberts also founded and participates in the GReen Energy At Texas (GREAT) program, which was formed between the University of Texas at Austin and Austin Community College.  GREAT aims to increase the number of community college student that earn degrees through targeted mentorship and research experiences.

Semiconductor quantum dots chemically functionalized with organic dye molecules offer an ideal interface for photon conversion. Quantum dots energized by light absorption can pass their energy to molecules at their surface, promoting them into spin-triplet exciton states. If formed in high quantity, pairs of spin-triplet excitons can undergo triplet fusion, a process that combines their energy to form a single high-energy spin-singlet state that can radiate light. Likewise, photoexciting the dye molecules can fuel triplet fusion’s inverse process, singlet fission, which creates pairs of triplet excitons that can each pass to the quantum dot to drive infrared light emission. These schemes require a key step, the transfer of a spin-triplet exciton across the quantum dot:molecule interface, yet an understanding of how the structure of these interfaces impacts the rate and efficiency of spin-triplet exciton transfer is elusive. To address this need, Professor Roberts at the University of Texas at Austin directs a team that employs controlled chemical synthesis, 2D NMR and femtosecond time-resolved spectroscopies, and electronic structure calculations. The research team investigates how the chemical structure of quantum dot:molecule interfaces formed by two complementary quantum dot materials of PbS and Si impact spin-triplet exciton transfer. This project contributes to the creation of new hybrid organic:inorganic junctions for light-driven production of energy and fuels as well as materials that use spin entanglement for quantum computation and information storage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Due to its ability to transmit energy and information through space, light plays a central role in nearly all aspects of human society. However, light has a peculiar property as its energy content is transmitted by photons, discrete particles whose energy must be matched to their intended application. Materials that reshape light, by combining the energy of multiple low-energy photons to generate high-energy photons (photon upconversion) or by using single high-energy photons to produce multiple low-energy ones (downconversion), can enable new light-driven technologies and optoelectronics.

In this project we designed hybrid structures comprised of inorganic quantum dots interfaced with organic ligands that capture light and use its energy to drive either photon upconversion or downconversion. Quantum dots are small nanocrystals whose light absorbing and emitting properties depend on their size while ligands are molecules that bind (ligate) to their surface. Light absorbed by a quantum dot can excite its electrons, whose energy can be passed to ligands at their surface. These ligands in turn can act as antennas for funneling energy to molecules in the surrounding environment. This can place these molecules into a particular type of excited state, known as a spin-triplet state, that can be long-lived on molecular timescales, lasting for hundreds of microseconds to milliseconds. Pairs of molecules in these long-lived states can collide and pool their energy together, deexciting one molecule while promoting the other into a high-energy state that can emit light, providing a means for achieving photon upconversion. In principle, this scheme can operate in reverse to drive downconversion.

However, for this light conversion approach to operate efficiently, energy must be able to readily transfer between quantum dots and ligands bound to their surface. To achieve this goal, we have performed studies aimed at understanding how the chemical structure of the interface formed by molecular ligands and quantum dots controls their ability to exchange energy. For our studies, we focused on three types of quantum dots comprised of different compounds that absorb and emit distinct colors of light: PbS (near-infrared), Silicon (green/red), and CsPbBr3 (blue).

In a set of studies, we found the rate of light-induced electron transfer PbS quantum dots to perylenediimide (PDI) electron accepting ligands could be controlled by altering the conformation adopted by these ligands on the quantum dots’ surfaces. By either introducing “spectator ligands” that cause PDIs to bend towards the PbS surface or reducing PDI aggregation that restricts their ability to bend towards the PbS surface, we could accelerate electron transfer. As electron transfer is related to energy transfer, design concepts from our work for structuring the ligand shell of PbS quantum dots can likewise be applied to speed energy transfer for photon upconversion.

In silicon quantum dots, we found energy can move back and forth along covalent silicon-carbon linkages formed between the dots and ligands anchored to their surface over nanosecond-to-microsecond timescales. This ability to exchange energy in different directions suggests silicon quantum dots can readily be used for both upconversion and downconversion. Importantly, by controlling the structure of covalent silicon-carbon links between quantum dots and ligands, we can push them into a strong coupling regime wherein photoexcited electrons are simultaneously shared between a dot and each ligand bound to its surface. Such states generate unique opportunities for moving energy between a dot and its environment as all ligands bound to a dot can potentially act as an energy donor following light absorption. In related work, we have found similar strongly coupled states can be formed in solid arrays of CdSe quantum dots through proper choice of surface ligands and act to accelerate energy diffusion through the array.

Lastly, we have examined how the chemical structure of the bridging group used to affix ligands to blue-absorbing CsPbBr3 quantum dots impacts their ability to fuel blue-to-UV photon upconversion. By binding naphthalene-based energy acceptors to CsPbBr3 dots via carboxylate linkers rather than amines and optimizing linker placement on acceptors, we can significantly speed energy transfer. This improved performance results from several factors, including stronger binding of carboxylates over amines to CsPbBr3 and stronger electronic coupling between naphthalene and CsPbBr3 facilitated by carboxylates.

In addition to our scientific results, we have worked to expand the STEM workforce via Connecting Research and Education A TExas (CREATE), a program that introduces community college students to modern STEM research through research seminars and a summer internship program. During this project, nearly forty students at Austin Community College completed research internships focused on areas related to chemistry and nanoscience at UT Austin. This project also developed a research-focused classroom exercise that can be integrated into organic chemistry courses to introduce students to research in a classroom environment. This exercise has been piloted by students at Austin Community College, who have successfully created a library of novel diketofurofuran dyes for applications in photon upconversion and downconversion.
